issue.title: Update Classic McEliece
issue.body:
Fixes #1314 and takes into account discussion from #1459. 

Changes SPDX line for `src\common\pqclean_shims\crypto_declassify.h` from MIT to CC0.

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [Yes] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [No] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: d5d8ccd216207f34515f7157d0b03953a353da05 fixes the version number and the issues regarding the comment. That leaves us with deciding whether or not to bump the SOVERSION.

issue.title: Trigger downstream CI ?
issue.body:
https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python/commit/f52b2650897b5b918b58d3c3d11cad79b6a2f219 removed CCI support in that subproject. https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1498 fixes the consequent CCI failure in `liboqs`.

This triggered the question for me whether we still want to trigger downstream CI (and/or for which subprojects) -- and (if/where) to consequently add/change the CI trigger logic (e.g., trigger downstream `github` actions instead of CCI)? 

From the perspective of testing integrations it would be goodness, but it puts responsibilities/can trigger work in downstream projects.

Somewhat related: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/182 adds a CCI trigger from oqs-provider to oqs-demos as (various) oqs-demos integrate oqs-provider. A similar trigger exists from oqs-openssl111 to oqs-demos. This leads to an inefficient repeated execution of oqs-demos CCI if `liboqs` changes trigger downstream CCI to both `oqs-openssl111` and `oqs-provider`. Can this be improved/are both necessary?

comment.body:
> I have a PR open for the liboqs-python side here: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python/pull/65

Thanks! Approved.

> so I assume it's OK?

Yes: If any of the triggered downstream fails, they tell us by email and status report at https://openquantumsafe.org/dashboard.html

issue.title: Create cross-platform docker images in github
issue.body:
- Become independent from CircleCI for docker image creation
- Create multi-architecture images
- Publish those to [Github Packages](https://github.com/features/packages) and [Docker Hub](https://hub.docker.com/)
- Automate release tagging for docker images

comment.body:
First implementation in #214. Feedback welcome [which platforms to activate](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/blob/674da82619b49b73d8d489bc83b2bb0e0c11d0e3/.github/workflows/linux.yml#L21-L24) and which apps to roll over to `github` CI. 

Shall we set a goal to completely replace CircleCI? @dstebila @christianpaquin ? 

Even more radical thought: Shall we work on replacing Travis and AppVeyor, too? This way we might do/become really good in one CI technology instead of "dabbling" in several...

issue.title: Programmatically load provider
issue.body:
Hi all, I was able to compile libqos and oqsprovider under windows, so I end up with oqsprovider.dll
I'm trying to integrate dll in my c++ code loading dll in some way as I do for "legacy" and "default" (even if that providers are not dll in my scenario)
`OSSL_PROVIDER_try_load(NULL, "oqsprovider", 1);`
but I can't load it. Do you have some advice for me on how can programmatically load provider?
thanks

comment.body:
> as I do with legacy and default

OK, if you already load legacy and default successfully, then the only reason for `oqsprovider` to not be successfully loaded are: 1) It's not in `ossl-modules` (as is legacy) OR 2) the environment variable `OPENSSL_MODULES` isn't set to the directory where the `oqsprovider` DLL is located OR 3) you linked in `liboqs` SHARED into `oqsprovider` and do not have `liboqs.dll` in the PATH. I'd _strongly_ urge to build `liboqs` statically (and link it as such to `oqsprovider`) to avoid situation 3.

issue.title: Missing algorithms even though enabled in liboqs
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I compiled `liboqs` in the following way:

```
build() {
    cmake -G Ninja -B build -S "${pkgname}-${pkgver//_/-}"\
        -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON \
        -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=None \
        -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX="${pkgdir}/usr" \
        -DOQS_ALGS_ENABLED=All \
        -DOQS_BUILD_ONLY_LIB=OFF \
        -DOQS_DIST_BUILD=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_AES_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_SHA2_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_SHA3_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_OPT_TARGET=x86-64 \
        -DOQS_STRICT_WARNINGS=ON \
        -Wno-dev
    ninja -C build
    ninja -C build gen_docs
}
```
The complete PKGBUILD can be found [here](https://aur.archlinux.org/cgit/aur.git/tree/PKGBUILD?h=liboqs).

Then I compiled oqs-provider with:

```
build() {
    cmake -B build -S "${_pkgname}-${pkgver}" \
        -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE='None' \
        -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX='/usr' \
        -Wno-dev
    cmake --build build
}
```
The full PKGBUILD is also [here](https://aur.archlinux.org/cgit/aur.git/tree/PKGBUILD?h=oqsprovider).

The issue is that I don't get all the available algorithms that I can use with `liboqs` directly. For example, 

```bash
$ openssl list -signature-algorithms -provider oqsprovider | grep sphincsshake
  sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
```

Only the NIST level 1 and fast variant of SPHINCS+ are available. Is this a known limitation or am I doing something wrong? 

The complete list of signature algorithms that I get from the oqs-provider is this:

```bash
openssl list -signature-algorithms -provider oqsprovider                    
  dilithium2 @ oqsprovider
  p256_dilithium2 @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_dilithium2 @ oqsprovider
  dilithium3 @ oqsprovider
  p384_dilithium3 @ oqsprovider
  dilithium5 @ oqsprovider
  p521_dilithium5 @ oqsprovider
  falcon512 @ oqsprovider
  p256_falcon512 @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_falcon512 @ oqsprovider
  falcon1024 @ oqsprovider
  p521_falcon1024 @ oqsprovider
  sphincssha2128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincssha2128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincssha2128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  sphincssha2128ssimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincssha2128ssimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincssha2128ssimple @ oqsprovider
  sphincssha2192fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p384_sphincssha2192fsimple @ oqsprovider
  sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Arch Linux
 - OpenSSL version: OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023 (Library: OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023)
 - Version: 0.5.0

comment.body:
> Yes 111 used some size-limited bit fields to list algorithms.

Ah, now I remember: It was the [auth bit field](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/caac43c14e23c1bc7350005af38f9a09ac2d3d78/ssl/ssl_local.h#L188-L252). This does not need touching in OpenSSL as we manipulate the core `ssl_cert_info` table now dynamically upstream (added in https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/19312). So in essence, activating all sig algs should now be possible without problems. Will create draft PR to have CI confirm this.

issue.title: Missing algorithms even though enabled in liboqs
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I compiled `liboqs` in the following way:

```
build() {
    cmake -G Ninja -B build -S "${pkgname}-${pkgver//_/-}"\
        -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON \
        -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=None \
        -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX="${pkgdir}/usr" \
        -DOQS_ALGS_ENABLED=All \
        -DOQS_BUILD_ONLY_LIB=OFF \
        -DOQS_DIST_BUILD=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_AES_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_SHA2_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_USE_SHA3_OPENSSL=ON \
        -DOQS_OPT_TARGET=x86-64 \
        -DOQS_STRICT_WARNINGS=ON \
        -Wno-dev
    ninja -C build
    ninja -C build gen_docs
}
```
The complete PKGBUILD can be found [here](https://aur.archlinux.org/cgit/aur.git/tree/PKGBUILD?h=liboqs).

Then I compiled oqs-provider with:

```
build() {
    cmake -B build -S "${_pkgname}-${pkgver}" \
        -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE='None' \
        -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX='/usr' \
        -Wno-dev
    cmake --build build
}
```
The full PKGBUILD is also [here](https://aur.archlinux.org/cgit/aur.git/tree/PKGBUILD?h=oqsprovider).

The issue is that I don't get all the available algorithms that I can use with `liboqs` directly. For example, 

```bash
$ openssl list -signature-algorithms -provider oqsprovider | grep sphincsshake
  sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
```

Only the NIST level 1 and fast variant of SPHINCS+ are available. Is this a known limitation or am I doing something wrong? 

The complete list of signature algorithms that I get from the oqs-provider is this:

```bash
openssl list -signature-algorithms -provider oqsprovider                    
  dilithium2 @ oqsprovider
  p256_dilithium2 @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_dilithium2 @ oqsprovider
  dilithium3 @ oqsprovider
  p384_dilithium3 @ oqsprovider
  dilithium5 @ oqsprovider
  p521_dilithium5 @ oqsprovider
  falcon512 @ oqsprovider
  p256_falcon512 @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_falcon512 @ oqsprovider
  falcon1024 @ oqsprovider
  p521_falcon1024 @ oqsprovider
  sphincssha2128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincssha2128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincssha2128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  sphincssha2128ssimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincssha2128ssimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincssha2128ssimple @ oqsprovider
  sphincssha2192fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p384_sphincssha2192fsimple @ oqsprovider
  sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  p256_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
  rsa3072_sphincsshake128fsimple @ oqsprovider
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Arch Linux
 - OpenSSL version: OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023 (Library: OpenSSL 3.1.1 30 May 2023)
 - Version: 0.5.0

comment.body: So, the (CI) test results are in (see e.g. [here](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/667/workflows/9f5b8da8-0daf-4dd7-bf51-89e7b6358665/jobs/1378)): Build time hardly changes; all tests pass but test times go up 3x-5x for the SIG tests: Sphincs+ _really_ is slow. So, to be nice to the environment (saving CI compute cycles) I'd suggest keeping the default sig algs enabled as-is unless someone (@iyanmv ?) makes a good case why enabling more, particularly slow Sphincs+, algorithms is a good idea.

comment.body: I don't have any good arguments to enable all by default. I thought it was a bug but it was just me not reading properly the README.

issue.title: enable all sig algs
issue.body: This is a "for fun" build activating all signature algorithms (to confirm https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/210#issuecomment-1630382729). Do not review/merge before we know runtime impact!

comment.body: After https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/210#issuecomment-1630598106 I'lll close this PR after tomorrow's meeting so that anyone interested can take a look at the CI results until then.

issue.title: Create cross-platform docker images in github
issue.body:
- Become independent from CircleCI for docker image creation
- Create multi-architecture images
- Publish those to [Github Packages](https://github.com/features/packages) and [Docker Hub](https://hub.docker.com/)
- Automate release tagging for docker images

comment.body: GitHub Actions does seem to be smoother running, so I don't mind if we migrate.  (Although aren't there are a few things where we need to stay with CircleCI, e.g. the PowerPC s390 testing that Basil set up?)  I also don't feel sufficiently strongly to make a huge push for a migration, so to me it would be an as-we-feel-like-it + new-things-go-on-GitHub-by-default migration.
